action.action-desc: Mr. Durbin (for himself and Mr. Hawley) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To establish legal standards for advanced artificial intelligence products.

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Aligning Incentives for Leadership, Excellence, and Advancement in Development Act or the AI LEAD Act.
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.
TITLE I—Aligning incentives for safety, innovation and United States competitiveness
Sec. 101. Developer liability for harm to business or consumer.
Sec. 102. Deployer liability for harm to business or consumer.
TITLE IV—Registration of foreign artificial intelligence system providers

paragraph.text: Artificial intelligence systems are products that shift decision-making power and responsibility away from humans to software-based systems, often without direct human oversight.

These products, while holding great promise, have caused and will cause harm to businesses and individuals. For example, multiple teenagers have tragically died after being exploited by an artificial intelligence chatbot.

Unpredictable allocations of liability jeopardize public safety and the financial well-being of both individuals and entire industries, particularly the small businesses of the United States, and adversely affect the Federal Government and taxpayers.

Product liability law can help to address harms caused by artificial intelligence systems that affect interstate commerce by incentivizing safety, providing certainty to artificial intelligence developers and deployers to continue to innovate, and ensuring the competitiveness of the United States.
A Federal products liability framework for artificial intelligence systems will remove barriers to interstate commerce and protect individuals’ due process rights.

This Act establishes Federal legislative guidelines for products liability without implicating expressive speech to ensure more predictable legal outcomes for individuals and industries and promotes business innovation.

subparagraph.text: The term artificial intelligence system means any software, data system, application, tool, or utility—

clause.text: that is capable of making or facilitating predictions, recommendations, actions, or decisions for a given set of human-or machine-defined objectives; and

that uses machine learning algorithms, statistical or symbolic models, or other algorithmic or computational methods (whether dynamic or static) that affect or facilitate actions or decision-making in real or virtual environments.

subparagraph.text: An artificial intelligence system may be integrated into, or operate in conjunction with, other hardware or software.

paragraph.text: The term claimant means any person, including a class of persons, who brings a liability action.
The term covered product means an artificial intelligence system.
The term deployer means a person, including a developer, who uses or operates a covered product for—

subparagraph.text: the person's own personal or commercial use; or
use by a third party.

paragraph.text: The term design, with respect to a covered product—

subparagraph.text: means the intended or known material characteristics of the covered product; and
includes—

clause.text: any intended or known formulation of the covered product and the usual result of the intended development or other processes used to produce the covered product, including unexpected skills or behaviors that appear in the covered product;
the selection of any data used for training a covered product through fitting its learnable parameters; and
training, testing, auditing, and fine-tuning the covered product.

paragraph.text: The term developer means a person who designs, codes, produces, owns, or substantially modifies a covered product for—

subparagraph.text: the person's own personal or commercial use; or
use by a third party.

paragraph.text: The term express warranty means any material, positive statement, affirmation of fact, promise, or description relating to a covered product, including any sample or model of a covered product.
The term harm means, with respect to the effect of the use of a covered product—

subparagraph.text: damage to property other than the covered product itself;
personal physical injury, illness, or death;
financial or reputational injury;
mental or psychological anguish, emotional distress, or distortion of a person’s behavior that would be highly offensive to a reasonable person; or
any loss of consortium or services or other loss deriving from any type of harm described in subparagraph (A), (B), (C), or (D).

paragraph.text: The term liability action means a civil action brought under section 301 based on any theory for harm caused by a covered product or covered product use.

The person means any individual, corporation, company, association, firm, partnership, society, joint stock company, or other entity, including any government entity or unincorporated association of persons.
The term substantial modification, with respect to a covered product—

subparagraph.text: means any deliberate change made to the covered product by a deployer that—

clause.text: was not authorized or reasonably anticipated by the developer when the covered product left the control of the developer; and
changes the purpose, use, function, design, or intended use or manner of use of the covered product from that for which the covered product was originally designed, tested, or intended; and

subparagraph.text: does not include a modification that solely reduces or mitigates a new or additional risk.

paragraph.text: The term under a legal disability, with respect to a person, means the person lacks the capacity to understand, make, or communicate decisions regarding the person's legal rights—

subparagraph.text: because of a mental illness or intellectual disability; or
because the person is under the age of 18.

title.header: Aligning incentives for safety, innovation and United States competitiveness

section.header: Developer liability for harm to business or consumer

subsection.text: In any liability action, the developer shall be liable to a claimant if the claimant establishes by a preponderance of the evidence—

paragraph.text: that—

subparagraph.text: the developer failed to exercise reasonable care with respect to the design of the covered product; and
the failure to exercise reasonable care was a proximate cause of harm to the claimant;

paragraph.text: that—

subparagraph.text: the developer failed to exercise reasonable care with respect to providing adequate instructions or warnings applicable to the covered product that allegedly caused the harm that is the subject of the complaint; and
the failure to exercise reasonable care with respect to providing adequate instructions or warnings was a proximate cause of harm to the claimant;

paragraph.text: that—

subparagraph.text: the developer made an express warranty applicable to the covered product that allegedly caused the harm that is the subject of the complaint;
the covered product failed to conform to the warranty; and
the failure of the covered product to conform to the warranty was a proximate cause of harm to the claimant; or

paragraph.text: that—

subparagraph.text: the covered product was, at the time of sale or distribution, in a defective condition unreasonably dangerous when used or misused in a reasonably foreseeable manner; and
the defective condition was a proximate cause of the harm to the claimant.

paragraph.text: In any liability action against a developer alleging that a covered product is unreasonably dangerous because of a defective design, as described in subsection (a)(1), the claimant shall be required to prove that, at the time of sale or distribution of the covered product by the developer, the foreseeable risks of harm posed by the covered product could have been reduced or avoided by the adoption of a reasonable alternative design by the developer, and the omission of the alternative design renders the covered product not reasonably safe.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1), in a liability action described in that paragraph, if the design of a covered product is found to be manifestly unreasonable, a claimant shall not be required to prove the existence of a reasonable alternative design.

paragraph.header: Circumstantial evidence supporting inference of covered product defect
paragraph.text: In a liability action described in subsection (a)(1), it may be inferred that the harm sustained by the claimant was caused by a covered product defect existing at the time of sale or distribution, without proof of a specific defect, when the incident that harmed the claimant—

subparagraph.text: was of a kind that ordinarily occurs as a result of covered product defect; and
was not, in the particular case, solely the result of causes other than covered product defect existing at the time of sale or distribution.

paragraph.header: Noncompliance and compliance with required covered product safety statutes or regulations

subparagraph.text: For purposes of a liability action described in subsection (a)(1), if a covered product does not comply with an applicable covered product safety statute or administrative regulation, the covered product shall be deemed defective with respect to the risks sought to be reduced by the statute or regulation.

For purposes of a liability action described in subsection (a)(1), the court may consider a covered product’s compliance with an applicable covered product safety statute or administrative regulation in determining whether the covered product is defective with respect to the risks sought to be reduced by the statute or regulation, but such compliance does not preclude as a matter of law a finding of covered product defect.

paragraph.text: For purposes of a liability action described in subsection (a)(2), a covered product shall be considered defective because of inadequate instructions or warnings if—

subparagraph.text: the foreseeable risks of harm posed by the covered product could have been reduced or avoided by the provision of reasonable instructions or warnings by the developer; and
the omission of the instructions or warnings renders the covered product not reasonably safe.

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1), an adequate instruction or warning is one that a reasonably prudent person in the same or similar circumstances would have provided with respect to a reasonably foreseeable risk and that communicates sufficient information on the reasonably foreseeable risks and safe use of the covered product, taking into account the characteristics of, and the ordinary knowledge common to, an ordinary user of the covered product.

In a liability action described in subsection (a)(2), the claimant shall be required to prove that, at the time the covered product left the developer’s control, the developer knew of or, in light of then-existing scientific and technical knowledge, reasonably should have foreseen, the risk that caused the claimant’s harm.

subparagraph.text: In a liability action described in subsection (a)(2), a developer shall not be liable for failure to instruct or warn about a foreseeable risk that is open and obvious to the user of the covered product, taking into account the characteristics of, and the ordinary knowledge common to, an ordinary user of the covered product.
For purposes of subparagraph (A), a risk shall be presumed to not be open and obvious to a user of a covered product who is under 18 years old.

paragraph.header: Noncompliance and compliance with required covered product safety statutes or regulations

subparagraph.text: In a liability action described in subsection (a)(2), if a covered product does not comply with an applicable covered product safety statute or administrative regulation, the covered product shall be deemed defective due to inadequate instructions or warnings with respect to the risks sought to be reduced by the statute or regulation.

In a liability action described in subsection (a)(2), the court may consider a covered product’s compliance with an applicable covered product safety statute or administrative regulation in determining whether the covered product is defective due to inadequate instructions or warnings with respect to the risks sought to be reduced by the statute or regulation, but such compliance does not preclude as a matter of law a finding of covered product defect.

subsection.header: Strict liability of developer for unreasonably dangerous or defective covered products

paragraph.text: In a liability action described in subsection (a)(4), the developer of a covered product shall be strictly liable for harm caused by the defective condition of the covered product, notwithstanding—

subparagraph.text: that the developer exercised all possible care in the design or distribution of the covered product; or
that the claimant did not purchase the covered product directly from the developer or otherwise enter into a contractual relationship with the developer.

paragraph.text: A developer shall not be liable under subsection (a)(4) for harm solely caused by a substantial modification.

section.header: Deployer liability for harm to business or consumer

subsection.text: A deployer shall be deemed to be liable as a developer under section 101 for harm caused by a covered product if—

paragraph.text: the deployer makes a substantial modification to the covered product; or
the deployer intentionally misuses the covered product contrary to its intended use and that misuse is the proximate cause of harm to the claimant.

subsection.header: Use intended by developer is not modification or misuse

paragraph.text: For purposes of subsection (a), a use of a covered product that is intended by the developer of the covered product does not constitute a substantial modification to or misuse of the covered product.
For purposes of paragraph (1), if a developer does not specify an intended use for a covered product, intended use shall be inferred by the targeted market and manner of distribution.

subsection.text: Subject to section 302, any deployer licensing a covered product shall not be liable to a claimant for a violation of section 101 solely by reason of ownership or use of the covered product.

paragraph.text: A developer may not include language in a contract with a deployer that waives any right, proscribes any forum or procedure, or unreasonably limits liability under this Act or applicable State law related to harm caused by the covered product under section 101.
Language in a contract that violates paragraph (1) shall be unenforceable.

A developer or a deployer may not include language in terms and conditions relevant to a covered product that waives any right, proscribes any forum or procedure, or unreasonably limits liability under this Act or applicable State law related to harm caused by the covered product under section 101 or 102.
Language in terms and conditions that violates paragraph (1) shall be unenforceable.

section.text: The Attorney General, any attorney general of a State, an individual or the legal representative of such an individual, or a class of individuals may bring a civil action in a district court of the United States against a developer or deployer for a violation of section 101, 102, or 201 to obtain—

paragraph.text: injunctive relief;
in a case brought by the Attorney General, civil penalties;
damages, restitution, or other compensation on behalf of individuals;
reasonable attorney fees and other litigation costs reasonably incurred; or
in a case brought by the Attorney General or a State attorney general, such other relief as the Attorney General or State attorney general may consider to be appropriate.

subsection.text: If the developer is not a party to a liability action because the developer is not subject to the court's jurisdiction, is insolvent, or cannot otherwise be made to answer for the harm, the deployer may be held liable to the same extent that the developer would have been liable under section 101.
A court shall dismiss the deployer from a liability action, upon motion, if—

paragraph.text: the developer—

subparagraph.text: is a party to the action; and
is subject to the court’s jurisdiction;

paragraph.text: the developer is not insolvent or otherwise unable to satisfy any likely judgment; and
the deployer is not otherwise liable under section 102.

If both the developer and the deployer contributed to the harm under sections 101 and 102, each person may be held jointly and severally liable for the portion of harm caused by that person's conduct.

Nothing in this subsection shall limit the right of a claimant to maintain a liability action against the developer, the deployer, or both, if the claimant can establish that each person contributed to the harm under sections 101 and 102.
A deployer that is held liable for harm caused by the developer under subsection (a) may pursue indemnification, including the recovery of attorney fees and litigation costs, from the developer.

If the deployer is determined to be at fault for a portion of the harm under subsection (c), indemnification under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be limited to the portion of damages, fees, or costs attributable to the conduct of the developer.

subsection.text: Nothing in this subsection shall limit the right of the claimant to maintain a liability action against the developer, the deployer, or both persons, if the claimant can establish that each person contributed to the harm under sections 101 and 102.

Except as provided in subsection (b), a liability action may be filed not later than 4 years after the date on which the claimant discovered or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered—

paragraph.text: the harm that is the subject of the action; and
the cause of the harm.

subsection.text: In the case of a person who is under a legal disability, the period of limitations under subsection (a) for a liability action brought by that person shall be tolled until the person ceases to be under a legal disability.
The period of limitations under subsection (a) shall be tolled from the date of the filing of a complaint against a developer or deployer to the date that a court enters a final judgment in the case.
This Act supersedes State law only where State law conflicts with the provisions of this Act.

Nothing in this Act shall prevent a State from enacting or enforcing protections that align with the principles of harm prevention, accountability, and transparency for a covered product that are stronger than such protections under this Act.

section.text: If any provision of this Act, or an amendment made by this Act, is determined to be unenforceable or invalid, the remaining provisions of this Act and amendments made by this Act shall not be affected.

title.header: Registration of foreign artificial intelligence system developers

subsection.text: Before making a covered product available in the United States, a foreign developer shall designate an agent for service of process.
The designation of an agent under subsection (a) shall—

paragraph.text: be in writing and submitted to the Attorney General;
include a written acceptance by the agent; and
specify the full legal name and address of both the foreign developer and the agent.

subsection.text: A designated agent under subsection (a) shall be a permanent resident of the United States.

A foreign developer of a covered product shall notify the Attorney General of any change to the designated agent under subsection (a) or the contact information thereof not later than 15 days after the change.
A foreign developer of a covered product that fails to designate an agent in accordance with section 401 may not deploy any covered product in the United States.
The Attorney General may seek injunctive relief to prevent a violation of subsection (a).

section.text: The Attorney General shall maintain a publicly accessible registry of designated agents of foreign developers of covered products.

This Act shall apply with respect to any liability action commenced on or after the date of enactment of this Act without regard to whether the harm that is the subject of the liability action or the conduct that caused the harm occurred before that date of enactment.
